author: Mitchell Garber
question: It's early in the game and match. Would you meld 4 wild cards that meet the point requirement (I.e. 125 points)? I would get 4 cards from the pack and my partner may have a wild card(s). Almost half of the cards are still in the deck. The other team hasn't melded yet.
context: Early game, 125 point requirement, half deck remaining, other team hasn't melded

responses.author: Gina Kaplan Katz
responses.text: I would not… I only meld wilds if I have at least 5. Remember you have restrictions on using wilds until the canasta of wilds is closed

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: I would just to get out.. I know they say it's safer with 5 but sometimes even with 5 wilds you don't make it...

responses.author: Barbara Magliozzi
responses.text: Depends how many hands have been played on how risky I will play. Say we are negative working in 125 and other team is close to winning and needs 180.

responses.author: April Volponi
responses.text: If you go for a wild card canasta like this, you don't want to waste a pick of the pack unless it is big enough to be worth it. No purpose in picking the pack for 4 cards.

responses.author: Neda Klein Couzens
responses.text: Depending on the score I definitely meld 4 wilds early on

responses.author: Paytra Ketelaars
responses.text: if you like taking risks, you go down with 4, if you like to play it safe, you wait until you have five

responses.author: Shelley Wohl Minsky
responses.text: Wait for 5 other team may be waiting to pick the pack

responses.author: Penny Goldner Reich
responses.text: The rule of thumb is to go down with five wilds. But there are always exceptions.

responses.author: Shelley Lieberman Stein
responses.text: I would. Do it all the time

recommendation: Strategic choice, not a rules question. Generally: Don't open with 4 wilds early - you lose flexibility and give opponents information. Keep wilds for picking piles and completing canastas.
strategy: Early game, preserve wild cards rather than melding them for opening points. The pack access and canasta completion value exceeds the opening benefit.

title: Keep cards in hand
strategy: Do not empty your hand matching every partner meld early. Holding cards preserves access to the pack and keeps options open.

title: Track aces and sevens
strategy: Track aces and sevens relentlessly. Avoid holding more than two aces or two sevens when aces are not yet safely mixed on the table.

title: Discard singles first
strategy: Prefer shedding higher-value singles early to keep lower points on the table for safer access later.

title: Evaluate special hand early
strategy: At the start of each hand, evaluate distance to a special hand before committing to ordinary melds. Decide early whether you aim for pairs or the zip code.

title: Watch every discard
strategy: Watch every discard, especially partner discards. That is live information for safety and bait.

title: Don't throw aces after partner opens with aces
strategy: Do not throw an ace immediately after your partner opens with aces. Give them time to use partner aces to pick a future pack.

title: Sevens management partnership
strategy: Sevens management is partnership strategy. Many teams allow a seven discard right after opening, especially when the opener's hand is short, or when targeting higher opening thresholds.

title: Avoid loading pile with sevens
strategy: Avoid loading the pile with sevens. Opponents picking that pile may convert it into a pure sevens canasta.

title: Late game baiting
strategy: Baiting late, you may throw a tempting rank that traps opponents into taking a bad pile filled with aces or sevens that will hurt them at scoring.

title: Safe discard based on closed ranks
strategy: Safe discard selection depends on what is already closed. If foes closed jacks, a jack becomes safer. If fours are dead, a four is safer.

title: Close mixed canasta early when risky
strategy: Closing a mixed canasta early is wise when your partner has few cards or when opponents have multiple threes down. Reduce risk, bank the base points.

title: Leave meld open only with upside
strategy: Leave a meld open only when the timing supports higher upside and opponents are unlikely to punish you.

title: High-value canasta decisions
strategy: Waiting one draw to try to complete a high-value canasta can swing thousands of points. Think, do not autopilot a pile pick that locks you into a lower ceiling.

title: Compare outcomes before taking late pile
strategy: Before taking a late pile, compare two outcomes: your projected score if you pass versus if you take the pile, including hits for aces and sevens remaining in hand. Take only if the swing is favorable.

title: Count threes carefully
strategy: Count threes carefully. Their swing can erase or create a lead late in the deal.

title: Agree on signals with partner
strategy: Agree with your partner on signals for aces and sevens policy and safe throws.

title: Announce card count
strategy: Keep your card count visible. Announce when at three or fewer cards. Announce the turn card.

title: Rack layout gives information
strategy: One straight rack reveals less information than multi-level racks. Multi-level racks expose your grouping and pairs to observant opponents. Sorting and handling matter - the less you reveal through spacing and rack layout, the better.

title: Maximize points over time in tournaments
strategy: In tournament play, maximize team points over time. Do not rush to end low-scoring deals unless time and position demand it.

title: Pacing and time management
strategy: Pacing matters. Manage time within each round. Aim to finish all four deals. If time expires mid-round in a tournament, the unfinished deal yields zero for both sides.

title: Early discard priority
strategy: Early with no wilds, discard a four or five before faces. Face cards tend to be hoarded longer.

title: Hold zip code pieces
strategy: Hold potential zip code pieces until you see a path. Do not break them prematurely.

title: Close when partner is low
strategy: With partner at three cards, closing a mixed canasta now is safer than chasing extra points.

title: Avoid giving pile access late
strategy: When both sides already closed multiple canastas and the pile is full of bad ranks, avoid throws that open the pile for them.

title: Leave fifth ace in hand
strategy: When you open with aces, leave the fifth ace in hand. Preserve partner's ability to pick a future pile topped with an ace.

title: Two-digit mental counter for tracking
strategy: Track sevens and aces with a simple two-digit mental counter. Tens place for aces. Ones place for sevens. Update every time you see one.

title: Mindful of player to the left
strategy: Be mindful of the person to the left when protecting the pack, but if you can, be mindful of everyone.

title: Throw matching rank to protect pack
strategy: Already have your own meld of 4s? Protect the pack by throwing a 4. It's more important to protect the pack than to have a bigger meld of 4s.

title: Keep extra wild for pack protection
strategy: Can close a canasta with 1 wild? Throw a 2nd wild so you have another card to throw to protect the pack. It still counts as mixed whether it has 1 or 2 wilds.

title: Never throw the 5th seven or ace
strategy: Be aware of how many 7s or aces are in the pack. Never throw the 5th to give opponents a pure canasta.

title: Hot seat awareness
strategy: If right hand opponent melded, you are in the hot seat. You need to be aware of what opponent on the left has thrown to not give the pack.

title: When signaling is discarded
strategy: Signaling is discarded when you are melding, when you need 180, or when the right partner has melded.

title: Which card to throw with 4 left
strategy: Have 4 cards left with 2 aces and 2 7s? Throw the one with the fewest in the pack - minimize risk of giving away a pure canasta.

title: Baiting with 3 of a kind
strategy: When you have 3 of a kind, throw one - it might bait them to give you a card you can use to pick the pack with your pair.

title: At 180, throw low cards
strategy: At 180 opening requirement, throw low cards even if you have a pair. You probably can't open with them anyway.

title: Rush to end with 3s advantage
strategy: Have a lot of 3s? Push for that 2nd canasta - they're worth a lot of points. Other team has a lot of 3s and no closed canasta? Rush to close the round to give them penalty points.

title: Place jokers before 2s
strategy: Don't get stuck with jokers in hand at the end of a round. Always place them first vs 2s - they are a much bigger penalty in hand than melded.

title: Safe cards for high pile counts
strategy: Keep safe cards for higher discard pile counts. Throw risky cards when the pile count is low.

author: Ester Himelblum-Zeller
question: I'm a fairly new player to Canasta and I have a question about the 3s. Red Three's I understand you place out and gets counted towards your points. What about the Black 3s. On line they are used as blockers but nobody I know uses them that way. They use them like the Red Three's. What is the correct way?
context: New player confused about black threes in Modern American Canasta vs online versions

responses.author: Andi Stone Katz
responses.text: Both color 3's are used the same way.

responses.author: Shelley Wohl Minsky
responses.text: Red or black 3s are counted in your points. Black 3s are not blockers. I don't know where you came up with that explanation.

recommendation: Both color 3's are used the same way.

author: Judy Hill
question: I play canasta w/ some girls that discard 7s and As indiscriminately early in the hand. They don't seem to protect them and are not signaling. Consequently when the time comes when you can pick a big pack many times you can make 7s or As. It doesn't seem to happen in other games I play in, but in this particular game and often. What is a good strategy for As and 7s? I always try to hold 2.
context: Strategy question about managing 7s and Aces when opponents discard them carelessly

responses.author: Elise Efrus
responses.text: Yes, if possible always keep 2 sevens in your hand. Aces too.

responses.author: Carol Nachenberg Shames
responses.text: Keep 2 7's and 2 Aces if you can. If the other team is down with Aces then you don't need to keep them in your hand.

recommendation: Yes, if possible always keep 2 sevens in your hand. Aces too.

author: Linda Ellis Finkelstein
question: If i have six of a kind in my hand and the person who discard before me throws the seventh card that I need to make a splash can I pick up that splash as my opening meld?
context: Rule clarification about splash/7-card meld from discard pile as opening meld

responses.author: Beth F. Levine
responses.text: Nope. A splash must be made from picking from the stock pile, not from picking the discard pack.

responses.author: April Volponi
responses.text: Only if you can first meet the requirements to open from your hand. Best practice -- take a pile and put it on the side. Open from your hand first.

recommendation: No. You cannot pick the pile to form a splash as your opening meld. You need a natural pair already in hand to legally pick the pile. The 7th card completes the splash AFTER you've legally picked.
strategy: To pick the pile for opening: you must have a natural pair in hand that matches the top discard, plus meet the point threshold. You cannot count cards you'll gain from the pile toward opening requirements.

author: Mimi Temkin Bass
question: We had 2 situations today and none of were 100% sure. Please don't simply say "it's a table rule" unless it really is a TABLE RULE. I opened with 5 two's and 2 big Jokers. I immediately put it down and was told it was only 2500 points. Is that correct for the official American Canasta rules. The second question is "if you ask your partner if you can go out? And you decide you still want to go out, can you still go out?
context: Two questions about wild card canasta scoring and going out after partner says no

responses.author: Bob Krakowsky
responses.text: The official canasta rules gives 2000 points for a mixed wild card canasta, 2500 if it contains all four jokers and 3000 points if it consists of 7 deuces. If your partner says no to going out, you can still decide if it does or doesn't make sense to go out.

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: Wild canasta is 2000. If you have 4 big jokers it is 2500. If you have all 2s it is 3000 points. If they say no, I would not go out.

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: I think if you have 4 big jokers it's 2500 point. All 2's canasta is 3000 points. If you asked your partner to go out and she says no and you still want to? You can.

responses.author: Devorah Ribak Turner
responses.text: You are allowed to go out even though your partner said no... However, you should think twice about the consequences.

responses.author: Sherri Sherman Sheerr
responses.text: The wilds point values aren't table rules. Signaling for them are.

responses.author: Rae Metsch Savett
responses.text: Even if they say NO, u can still go out.

responses.author: Kathy Weisman Wolf
responses.text: If you ask your partner if you can go out and she says NO then she probably has 7's or A's to clear.

recommendation: Two questions answered: (1) A mixed wild canasta (5 twos + 2 jokers = 7 cards) earns the 2,500 bonus - that's correct. (2) Asking partner is BINDING - if they say yes, you MUST go out. If they say no, you cannot go out that turn.
strategy: The 'asking to go out' rule is strict: partner's answer is binding. Plan your hand before asking.

author: Joyce Gruber Zappulla
question: A question came up in yesterday's game. If a player picks the final card, can they use all of their cards on their melds, with the exception of a card to throw on the discard pile. This would leave the player with no cards.
context: Question about picking the final card and playing all cards except discard

responses.author: Andrea Butterweich
responses.text: Except for special hands you always need a discard

responses.author: Stephanie Adler Calliott
responses.text: If I'm reading this correctly, yes -- if you have two closed canastas. No, if you don't. You'd need a discard and card in your hand (if you can't go out).

responses.author: Dara Collins
responses.text: Every turn (other than getting a Special Hand) must end in a discard

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: They can not go out unless they have 2 closed canastas and do not have open A, 7, or Wild canasta on table. If they have met the requirements to go out, then they can play all the cards to the table and discard the final card face down. If not, they can play what can be played but retain one card in hand and one to discard.

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: Cannot do unless her melding created 2 closed canastas.

responses.author: Bruce Monte Sr.
responses.text: No, from what I have read the player who picks the last card must make a discard (assuming they are not going out) and the next player can pick the discard pile if they have the pair and their side is down.

responses.author: Linda Kimmel
responses.text: Only if going out

responses.author: Barbara Magliozzi
responses.text: Yes if they closed A's, 7's, wild canastas and had 2 canastas.

responses.author: Gayle Kollitz
responses.text: That is called going out.

recommendation: No. You must always discard to end your turn. The only exception is going out - and even then, most rules require a final discard. Drawing the last card doesn't exempt you from discarding.
strategy: Every turn ends with a discard. If you cannot legally discard (only wilds in hand, pack frozen), you're stuck.

author: Faye Gilad
question: When playing yesterday, a player only had wild cards in hand, therefore a wild card was used as a discard. On next pick another wild card was obtained. Now she had 4 wilds in hand. Player wanted to use one of the wilds to close a meld of fives on the table for a mixed canasta and then discard a wild card. Is this allowed to be done?
context: Question about using wild cards when only holding wilds - can you close a canasta and discard a wild?

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: Yes. As long as she only has wild cards in her hand, she can close other canastas & then use another wild card to discard to the tray.

responses.author: Leslie Carol Berg Weiss
responses.text: For MAC, yes. Discarding the wild means the wild card gets thrown into the discard and faces the same way as the turn card. The pack under and including the discarded wild is now frozen and cannot be taken.

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: Yes, you can. You can close your canasta and throw out the wild.

responses.author: Barbara Magliozzi
responses.text: Yes, a wild card can be used as long as no other card in hand. Last card also goes face down so can be anything.

responses.author: Brooke Nero
responses.text: Is the freeze pack rule with a wild really a written rule anywhere?

responses.author: Roni Goodman Sederquist
responses.text: Yes!

responses.author: Stephanie Waldman Kreiner
responses.text: No. If she had another card besides a joker she had to discard that. Unless she was going out.

responses.author: Carla Butcher
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Debbie Meyer
responses.text: Yes it is.

recommendation: Yes, you can. You can close your canasta and throw out the wild.

author: Carol Lucchesi
question: Was at a card party, and one of the players said in her other game you can put a dead card, 7s or Aces in an empty bin. I told her I never heard that could be a table rule. Then it seem like many things are allowed to be a table rule. My instructor yelled out "It's the Canasta God's rule!" when someone asked her that question.
context: Question about whether dead cards, 7s or Aces can be discarded into empty tray - answered NO, this is not a table rule, it's a core canasta rule

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: No not true! No table rule it's canasta law! No 7's or A's or dead cards on an empty tray.

responses.author: Jackie Schweitzer Guerrera
responses.text: I've never heard that as a table rule. It's a canasta rule.

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: In current game play modern American canasta the answer would be NO. Not in the game and not as a table rule. Empty tray can not take SWAD - Seven Wild Dead or Ace.

responses.author: April Volponi
responses.text: Some things are negotiable; some should never be. They are changing the game...

responses.author: Robin Hammer
responses.text: I'm now playing in a game where you can put a dead card in an empty tray. Every game I play in is different.

responses.author: Linda Gaddis
responses.text: No A's, 7's or dead cards can be discarded into an empty tray. Modern Canasta and Real Canasta rule.

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: THAT IS NOT A TABLE RULE!! It is a general rule to follow in every game every day! Those people need to reread and learn how to play the game correctly. Need lessons.

responses.author: Kathy Weisman Wolf
responses.text: An ace, seven or a dead card can never be thrown into an empty tray... Canasta 101

recommendation: No not true! No table rule it's canasta law! No 7's or A's or dead cards on an empty tray.

author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
question: I am playing Real Canasta and the Robot melded with a straight canasta of 10's- is that allowed in a regular game?
context: Question about opening with a clean canasta

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: Yes it is. Because 7 cards of any type clean equals 500 points which is more than enough to meld. But… you must have 7 clean cards to do it.

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: If you mean that they opened with a clean canasta of 7 10s, yes. It is called a Splash when one opens that way and meets the opening requirement.

recommendation: Yes it is. Because 7 cards of any type clean equals 500 points which is more than enough to meld. But… you must have 7 clean cards to do it.

author: Andrea Pilnik Ceasar
question: Playing with my group and teaching someone to play. With regards to 3's - Can you hold on to a 3 until your next turn and then discard just in case you are trying for a special hand. I disagree. What's the rule? And if you have to keep the 3 in your hand are you allowed to go out by discarding the 3.
context: Question about holding 3s and discarding them to go out

responses.author: Andi Stone Katz
responses.text: If you hold a 3 after your initial draw, you keep in your hand. Some groups play that it is -5 points at the end of the game. You cannot discard it to go out.

responses.author: Donna Wilson Nuss
responses.text: The rule is you have to keep it in your hand if you forgot to put it down.

recommendation: If you hold a 3 after your initial draw, you keep in your hand. Some groups play that it is -5 points at the end of the game. You cannot discard it to go out.

author: JoAnn Matray
question: Why wasnt this a special pairs hand? (Screenshot showing hand with pairs of 4,4,5,5,6,6,8,8,J,A and 2,2 wilds)
context: Question about special pairs hand requirements with wild cards

responses.author: Bena Hoberman Weil
responses.text: You needed a pair of 7's

responses.author: Lisa Fox
responses.text: Because when you have wilds, you need aces and sevens.

recommendation: Not a valid pairs hand because it contains wild cards (the 2,2). A special pairs hand requires exactly 7 NATURAL pairs - no wild cards allowed. The 2s are wilds, not a natural pair.
strategy: Special hands (pairs, garbage) must be entirely natural cards. Any wild card invalidates the special hand.

author: Jo-Ann Taylor
question: I threw a card & the person to my left picked up the pack. There were about 5-6 cards in the pack. The person didn't have a single card to throw out legitimately, so she put the top card back in the empty pile without all the other cards & kept them in her hand. Is that how it's supposed to go?
context: Question about picking up pile without valid discard

responses.author: Gina Kaplan Katz
responses.text: No she needs to use the top card with the 2 in her hand or put back the whole pile

recommendation: No she needs to use the top card with the 2 in her hand or put back the whole pile

author: Cindy Pardes Salik
question: Looking for the post about signaling jokers. I never heard that.
context: Question about signaling wild cards to partner

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: The only way I could think of you'll be signaling that you have wild cards, as if you only have wild cards in your hand and no natural cards to discard.

responses.author: Shelley Wohl Minsky
responses.text: Total cheating- your first throw is a high card if you have 3 or more wilds if your first throw is a low card you have 2 wilds or less.

recommendation: Signaling (for jokers or anything else) is a partnership/table convention, not an official rule. There's no standard signal - agree with your partner before play.
strategy: Partnership signals are table rules. Common conventions exist but vary. Discuss with partner pregame.

author: Luann Shuer Garber
question: If you picked up the pile for aces and have 3 aces melded and 3 aces in your hand when the game ends, you're penalized 2500 points each. And if you have three 7s in your hand you are penalized another 2500 points. Are these aces and 7s in your hand counted again as deducted points?
context: Question about penalty scoring for aces and 7s

responses.author: Christine Allan
responses.text: If the three aces or 7's are on the table it's 2500 penalty. If they are in your hand it's 1500 points. Also counted as minus in your hand.

responses.author: Carol Lucchesi
responses.text: I'm confused...

recommendation: Yes, it's a double penalty. You get the 2,500 point penalty for failing to complete the pure canasta, AND those cards count against you at face value (aces = 20 each, 7s = 5 each). Both penalties apply.
strategy: Aces and 7s in hand at game end: 2,500 penalty per incomplete set PLUS the card point values. Very costly - prioritize completing or avoiding these melds.

author: Linda Ellis Finkelstein
question: Can someone explain how to score the points still in your hand if you leave open a wild card canasta specifically if 1. you had zero other canastas 2. You had one closed canasta. And if you had at least two closed canastas
context: Question about scoring with open wild card canasta

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: If you melded wild cards and do not close them, they are -2000 points. If you have one Canasta just your Canasta counts which is 500.

responses.author: Mark Wheeler
responses.text: The points still in your hand are always subtracted, regardless of the number of canastas, and regardless of any open 7, clean, or wild canastas.

recommendation: An open (incomplete) wild canasta is NOT a canasta - it's just a meld. You cannot go out without 2 complete canastas. The cards in an open wild meld count against you at face value (50 per joker, 20 per 2) plus you may face the 2,500 penalty if you started it and can't finish.
strategy: Never start a wild canasta unless you can complete it. An abandoned wild meld is extremely costly.

author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
question: While playing real canasta on line I had a lot of 3's and already made 2 canastas.. my opponent went out afterwards with a Special hand- So my canastas and 3's are counted but what ever was left in my and my partners rack is subtracted for points?
context: Question about scoring when opponent goes out with Special Hand

responses.author: Simma Levin Ferber
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Modern American Canasta
responses.text: When a Special Hand is made, it ends the round and scoring takes place.

recommendation: Yes

author: Ellen Krell Seckler
question: Can your initial meld be just a dirty ace canasta or do you still need a 3 of a kind?

comments.author: Bonnie Esserman Gershenzon
comments.text: Absolutely need 3 of a kind meld and points required (ie 125, 155 and 180).

author: Catherine Komor Merritt
question: When playing 2 person… how many cards are dealt?

comments.author: Fran Ofshe Korman
comments.text: 15 cards are dealt with 2 players and you pick 2 cards not 1.

comments.author: Jeffrey Lynn
comments.text: 13, draw 2 at a time, no pair hands. I have played it many times

author: Sharon Twomey
question: Anyone have rules/tips for playing 6 person Canasta? Three teams

comments.author: Andrea Butterweich
comments.text: I like playing with 3 teams when theres 6 people. One team rotates out for a hand, keep 3 columns for scoring so each team gets their points.

author: James Barnes
question: Are there specific rules for tournaments?

comments.author: Modern American Canasta
comments.text: Tournament Directors set their own rules. When we hosted our Tournament in NYC, we shared the rules in advance with players...

comments.author: Rose Marie
comments.text: Yes not all you are going to like..lol

author: Stephanie Adler Calliott
question: Picking the pack when an Ace is the top card means you may only use it for a clean Ace canasta, right? Some people Ive played with have said if you already have a dirty meld of aces, you may pick the ace from the pack and add it to your existing dirty meld.

comments.author: May Mitlitsky Jaffe
comments.text: If you pick it up and already have an existing dirty meld of As on the table you can add to that pack. Otherwise it does have...

comments.author: Randy Hibshman
comments.text: Correct- you can add to the dirty aces

author: Shevawn Scanlon Everett
question: The final card in the deck is a 3. Lots of table rules here. Looking for THE rule most groups follow. Want to follow CLA /MAC accepted rules.

comments.author: Modern American Canasta
comments.text: As the admins of this group, we play and teach by the rules we documented in Modern American Canasta: The Complete Guide...

comments.author: Judy Hill
comments.text: We play hold in your hand as 5 point penalty - game over- since you cant pick a replacement card...

author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
question: My opponent made a special hand. My partner already made 2 canastas with 3s. The question is our canastas and 3s and whatever is on the table still counts? I think it does but I am just checking.

comments.author: Diana Hibbard LoCascio
comments.text: Everybody I know plays that you just end the hand with the special hand as if somebody went out playing regularly. The other team...

comments.author: Ginger Lindsey
comments.text: Hmm, my thinking is that your opponents get only the score for the special hand, and nothing else, but your team gets to count...

author: Chris Bradley
question: Question on scoring. My books give two different answers. If a player has open 7s laid and opponents go out, how are the open 7s scored? Does it matter if they have a separate closed canasta? (I know they cant go out with open 7s)

comments.author: Linda Ann Sullivan
comments.text: Yes, even with the -2500 penalty for an incomplete 7s Canasta, you do get the 5 points for each 7 in your meld (on the table)...

author: Barbara Magliozzi
question: Please explain signaling and how to do it? Thanks. How do I signal I have 7's or A's?

responses.author: Harold Moses
responses.text: signaling for wild cards, If you are dealt three or more wild cards, you throw a 10 point card as your first discard. That's the signal to your partner that you have 3 or more wild cards in your hand. Then if your partner throws a 10 point card on their next turn, that signals to you that they have two or more wild cards in their hand. Therefore you can now account for at least 5 wildcard between the two of you and are you well positioned to get a wild card canasta. I've never play that way by the way.

responses.author: Carol Berman
responses.text: I've always signaled 7a and As That is how I learned but I don't think signaling wild cards was ever an accepted part of the game I know people use that strategy but my personal opinion is it shouldn't be done Again personal opinion

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: Signaling is letting your partner know you have many Ace's, 7's or wild's. In theory if you start out and have have lots of wilds you would throw a very high card as your first throw. If you have lots of 7's you would throw a 7 so your partners knows. As for Ace's I am not sure. But, this only works if your partner and you discuss this before.

responses.author: Leslie Carol Berg Weiss
responses.text: I usually play with my husband and we generally signal for 7s but not As because we try to open with dirty As. Let's say I have three 7s before I open; I will throw out one 7. He now knows that I have two 7s left because generally there's no other reason to discard a 7 before we've opened.

responses.author: Cathy Ericson
responses.text: Never heard of it! We are playing about 4 years. We were taught by canasta teachers. We would call that cheating, no signaling of any sort in my game and I'm teaching now.

responses.author: Marleen Leventhal
responses.text: Generally, when someone opens with more than two sevens, they will throw one of their sevens to indicate to their partner that they have more than two. It is definitely not cheating. It is strategy. The person who initially throws the seven keeps track of how many sevens are in the pile, and will attempt to pick the pile if there are 5 because she still has the two in her hand and will therefore have a clean 7 canasta.

recommendation: I've always signaled 7a and As That is how I learned but I don't think signaling wild cards was ever an accepted part of the game I know people use that strategy but my personal opinion is it shouldn'

author: Millie Arana
question: Hi, Questions always come up when we are playing and one was: With a meld of 7s there is a penalty of 2,500 points, but can the team still add the 5 points worth of each of those 7s to the overall count for that hand?

responses.author: Leslie Carol Berg Weiss
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Jim Weiss
responses.text: How about: YES!

responses.author: Abigail Urban Rifkin
responses.text: You have two different counts. The base, which includes your canastas and your meld and your 3's. If you have at least two canastas, you count your threes in your base. One canasta, you do not count your threes in Then you have your count, which includes all your cards minus the count in both your hands. So the quick answer is yes, you 7's count as 5 points each. You also have a minus 2500 for open 7's.

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: Yes. If on the table uncompleted you deduct 2500 points but then you add the individual 7's to your total points.

responses.author: Debbie Sanders
responses.text: Absolutely!

recommendation: Yes

author: Gail Vogel Weisberg
question: Can you pick up the pack with your initial meld with the top card an ace when your initial meld with the proper count includes two aces and a joker?

responses.author: Modern American Canasta
responses.text: If an Ace is the top card and you have a Mixed Ace Meld, the most widely played rule as documented in our book, is that it can not be picked when Opening.

responses.author: Jim Weiss
responses.text: No additional responses necessary!

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: On opening it's the only time you can not pick up the pack when even though you have two Aces and a joker. But you can pick up the pack if you are going for a pure Ace Canasta. I think I am correct on that

recommendation: If an Ace is the top card and you have a Mixed Ace Meld, the most widely played rule as documented in our book, is that it can not be picked when Opening.

author: Luann Shuer Garber
question: If you have a mixed wild card canasta for 2500 point, are the wild cards counted again in total card points?

responses.author: Jamie Lewin Meadow
responses.text: Wild card canasta is 2000. 4 Jokers included 2500. All 2's 3000. If you close any canasta you count everything on the table

responses.author: Andi Stone Katz
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: Jaimie is correct 2,000 points for a mixed wild canasta

responses.author: Carol Nachenberg Shames
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Donna Bottone Bianco
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Larry Schiller
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Ronald Feingold
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: Yes

recommendation: Yes

author: Carol Roth Barack
question: Picking the pack when doing an opening meld, can you used the 2 cards with a joker in your meld count to pick the pack?

responses.author: Kathy Weisman Wolf
responses.text: Yes as long as you have full count in your hand without the top card in the pack you are picking

responses.author: Brooke Nero
responses.text: Yes. Here's is how I teach this rule as it can be confusing: Announce you are going to pick the pack and remove it and place it next to the turner. Lay down cards from your hand for the required point count. Everyone verifies point count. If you have a pair on the table that matches the top card in the pile you can proceed. The pair can be from a clean triple, OR cards with wilds. OR it can be from another pair in your hand that you have not laid down for the initial meld points.

responses.author: Barbara Magliozzi
responses.text: No if you mean you have 2 jokers and think you can pick any top card. You need 2 naturals in hand. Then you can only add jokers depending on meld base of the table.

responses.author: Amy Pressler
responses.text: You place down your opening meld first while the pack is to the side. If you placed down two Naturals and wild and they match the top card then you add that top card to the meld. Any new meld after the initial would have to follow along with the rule of having 5 cards before adding a wild.

responses.author: Diana Hibbard LoCascio
responses.text: Yes. If your pair matches the top card and you are successfully open, you can pick the pile. You just can't use the top card on the pile as part of your open. It's a separate stage of your turn.

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: You can't use 2 jokers or wilds to pick the pack. You need two of a kind to pick the pack always.

recommendation: Yes as long as you have full count in your hand without the top card in the pack you are picking

author: Mara Hirschhorn Mazen
question: If you have 2 cards in your hand one is a joker and the other is a jack, I have 4 jacks on the table can I put the jack that was in my hand on the table and go out with the joker?

responses.author: Penny Goldner Reich
responses.text: In my games you could not put a wild card on the jacks. We play a meld base of 5.

responses.author: Modern American Canasta
responses.text: When Going Out, any card can be discarded since it is placed facedown.

responses.author: Aleza Aron-Bayof Cory
responses.text: Why wouldnt you put the joker on the jacks and then put the jack in the deck to go out, the joker is worth more points

responses.author: Marcia Weisman
responses.text: Yes, because the last card is face down and no one knows what it is anyway. Yes, if you have two canastas on the table and no open aces or sevens.

responses.author: Dale Herman
responses.text: Yes, but why not put the wild down and go out with the J? More points.

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: Did you have 2 canastas to go out? It wasn't mentioned!

responses.author: Gayle Kollitz
responses.text: Yes. But better to put Joker on Jacks meld and discard Jack.

recommendation: No. You cannot discard a joker (wild card) as your final card if you have any other legal discard option. Since you had a jack, you must discard the jack. The joker must be melded or held.
strategy: Wild cards can only be discarded if they're your ONLY card, and even then it freezes the pack. Never plan to go out by discarding a wild.

author: Anne Bombard
question: Still confused…..does a discarded wild freeze the pack or not? What is the actual rule, not the 'how we play' rule.

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: Yes, in a real game it freeze the pack - but in real Canasta it doesn't. I think that is the answer you are going to get. Don't be confused - just ask at your table how they would like to play

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: Yes it freezes the pack!!

responses.author: Leslie Carol Berg Weiss
responses.text: Turn the card sideways in the discard and that card and everything under it can no longer be picked up

responses.author: Neda Klein Couzens
responses.text: Modern American Canasta it is turned sideways and pack is frozen

responses.author: Gail Grant
responses.text: Never heard of that rule. If that is all you have to throw, you throw it as any other card. It doesn't 'freeze' the deck.

responses.author: Judy Hoffman Connick
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: Yes. Turn sideways

responses.author: Christine Allan
responses.text: Can only discard a wild card if that's all you have in your hand. Otherwise play the wild card on the table and discard the non wild card.

responses.author: Caroline Dann
responses.text: No that's 1940's rule!! The pack is never frozen but be careful if you take for the wild they must be melded and if not closed or minus 2000

recommendation: Yes, a discarded wild card freezes the pack. The wild goes sideways on the pile to indicate frozen status. If someone picks the pile after the wild, they only get cards down to (and including) the wild - nothing below it.
strategy: Discarding a wild is rare and defensive - it freezes the pack and limits what opponents can pick up.

recommendation: Everyone must count after a meld. Ask the melder to HOLD before discarding and picking up the talon. If there is a mismeld, things need to be undone, and it's better if undone before the talon is picked up.
If both teams have the same meld (e.g., both opened with 2 6s and an ace), but one team closes that meld into a canasta, the other team cannot add more cards to that meld after it's been closed.
If you pick the pack to open, you don't get the talon.
Hold as many pairs as possible to put pressure on opponent and pick the pack over and over until you no longer want to.
Count aces and sevens in the discard pile.
Keep 2 sevens in hand unless towards end of play or no other safe card.
Got 5 sevens or wilds early? Lay them down. Your partner likely has the last ones.
For wild card melds, 2s and jokers count as pure meld so you don't need another pure meld to assist the open. You can't add wild cards to other melds until you're done though.
Understanding timing is crucial: beginning vs middle vs end of round. How to play differently at each stage is IMPORTANT for mastery.
If another team has a meld of 4 pure, any other card of that value is a safe discard.
End of round: discard higher point value cards first.
End of round: about to get to 8500? Play safe. Opponent about to get 8500? Play hard.
First thing when round starts: look for special hands.

Once you put the 5th pure on a meld, you can no longer pick the pack with it, but you can close a mixed meld. However if your opponent puts the 5th card down, that's a safe discard because they can no longer pick the pack with it.
Once you hit the turn card, count 3s. Are all 8 out? If not, be careful as you may not get the turn you need.
Remember you can look back 3 cards once per turn.
How likely are you to pick the card you need for a special hand? If you need a joker, it's low since there are only 4 in the stock as opposed to 8 of each other type of card.
Discard 4-6 first. Then discard kings to 8s backwards.
Mismeld is a -10 point penalty.
If you showed 7s, aces or wild cards, you can't meld those pure anymore. Always meld face down until you know for sure you have the required point totals.
Talon after discard, not before.

author: Steve Lang
question: My partner and I have 4 Queens attempting to make a Canasta. My opponent throws down a Queen. My question(s) is: 1. Do I take the Queen ONLY from the discard pile? Or 2. Do I take the Queen and the rest of the discard pile?
context: Player confused about whether to take just top card or entire discard pile when picking

responses.author: Amy Feingold Stein Meyer
responses.text: You have to have 2 Queens to even take the queen and you ALWAYS have to take the whole pile.

responses.author: Sandy Garcia
responses.text: You take the pile

recommendation: When picking the discard pile, you ALWAYS take the entire pile, not just the top card. You need a natural pair (2 Queens in hand) to legally pick the pile.

author: Carol Stone Elover
question: When playing canasta for 2: 1) do you play the Rule of 5? 2) when you meld, do you take the extra cards? 3) do you get an additional card when you lay down a 3? 4) when you get to the talon, do you still pick 2 cards?
context: Questions about 2-player canasta variant rules

responses.author: Pat Lenaghan
responses.text: My husband and I play two hand frequently, deal 15 cards instead of 11, draw is two cards, must have 2 canastas to go out. Use two decks of cards.

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: [Posted image with rules reference]

recommendation: 2-player canasta has variant rules: Deal 15 cards (not 11), draw 2 cards per turn, must have 2 canastas to go out. Rule of 5 typically still applies. When you reach the talon, you may draw only 1 card if only 1 remains.
complexity_note: 2-player variant has different rules than standard 4-player

author: Carole Baron Brandwein
question: Can you go down with 5 of a kind and 2 wilds as an initial meld? It is a Canasta worth 300 points.
context: Question about opening meld requirements - can you open with only a mixed canasta

responses.author: Deborah Continelli Barenfeld
responses.text: No you need to have a clean triple to go down.

responses.author: Gail Vastola
responses.text: Has to be a clean canasta

responses.author: Rhea Abelson Feinberg
responses.text: Yes. But need a clean.

responses.author: Shelley Weinrod Roseman
responses.text: No

responses.author: Diane Levy-Rubinstein
responses.text: You can go down with a clean triple and a 5 cards with 2 jokers. As long as it = what the meld needs to be

responses.author: Rita Hirshman Trokenheim
responses.text: And a clean triple

responses.author: Robin Levine
responses.text: You would need a clean triple in order to do that with 5 of the same card and 2 wilds.

responses.author: Debbi Moldawer Sobel
responses.text: You must additionally have a clean canasta

responses.author: Betty Dwyer Holwitt
responses.text: Nope, need a clean three

responses.author: Estel Punsky Silverstein
responses.text: You need a clean triple in your meld

recommendation: No. You cannot open with ONLY a mixed canasta (5 of a kind + 2 wilds). Your opening meld MUST include at least one clean triple (3 natural cards of the same rank). The 'Rule of 5' applies: you need 5 natural cards before adding wilds to a meld.
strategy: Always include at least one clean triple in your opening meld. A mixed canasta alone is never sufficient to open.

author: Carol Stone Elover
question: When playing canasta for 2: 1) do you play the Rule of 5? 2) when you meld, do you take the extra cards? 3) do you get an additional card when you lay down a 3? 4) when you get to the talon, do you still pick 2 cards?
context: 2-player Canasta rules questions

responses.author: Pat Lenaghan

recommendation: 2-player Canasta rules: Deal 15 cards (not 11). Draw 2 cards per turn. Must complete 2 canastas to go out. Use 2 decks. Continue drawing 2 cards even when reaching the talon.

author: Carole Baron Brandwein
question: Can you go down with 5 of a kind and 2 wilds as an initial meld? It is a Canasta worth 300 points.
context: Question about opening with a mixed canasta (5 naturals + 2 wilds = 7 cards)
recommendation: Yes, you can open with a mixed canasta (5 naturals + 2 wilds). A mixed canasta is worth 300 points and easily meets any opening point requirement. This is valid as your initial meld.

author: Janice Satterlee
question: I called a special hand. I started laying out my cards when I realized my partner and I had more points already on the table than my special hand was worth. I did not lay down all my cards. Could I have picked my cards up and not call the special hand?
context: Can you abort a special hand after starting to lay it down?
recommendation: Once you begin laying down cards for a special hand, you are committed. You cannot pick them back up. The lesson: evaluate your position BEFORE starting to lay down a special hand - compare the special hand value against your current table points plus going-out bonus.

author: Carole Baron Brandwein
question: Can you go down with 5 of a kind and 2 wilds as an initial meld? It is a Canasta worth 300 points.
context: Question about opening with a mixed canasta (5 naturals + 2 wilds = 300 points)

responses.author: Deborah Continelli Barenfeld
responses.text: No you need to have a clean triple to go down.

responses.author: Gail Vastola
responses.text: Has to be a clean canasta

responses.author: Rhea Abelson Feinberg
responses.text: Yes. But need a clean.

responses.author: Shelley Weinrod Roseman
responses.text: No

responses.author: Diane Levy-Rubinstein
responses.text: You can go down with a clean triple and a 5 cards with 2 jokers. As long as it = what the meld needs to be

responses.author: Rita Hirshman Trokenheim
responses.text: And a clean triple

responses.author: Robin Levine
responses.text: You would need a clean triple in order to do that with 5 of the same card and 2 wilds. And if you have 5 cards with 2 wilds plus the clean triple you can absolutely close the Canasta upon open... In order to get a Splash you would need 7 of the same card upon open and you wouldn't need the clean triple because it covers your meld point requirements and a splash can do that. A mixed Canasta cannot, unless it's a Mixed Wild Card Canasta (with Jokers and Deuces) with 7 wild cards on open as that would be 2500 points and would not require the clean triple.

responses.author: Debbi Moldawer Sobel
responses.text: You must additionally have a clean canasta

responses.author: Betty Dwyer Holwitt
responses.text: Nope, need a clean three

responses.author: Estel Punsky Silverstein
responses.text: You need a clean triple in your meld

recommendation: No, you cannot open with just a mixed canasta (5+2 wilds). Your opening meld MUST include a clean triple (3 natural cards of the same rank with no wilds). Exceptions: a Splash (7 natural cards = 500+ points) or a wild canasta (7 wilds = 2500 points) do not require a clean triple because they exceed the meld requirements on their own.

author: Carol Stone Elover
question: When playing canasta for 2: 1) do you play the Rule of 5? 2) when you meld, do you take the extra cards? 3) do you get an additional card when you lay down a 3? 4) when you get to the talon, do you still pick 2 cards?

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: (Posted 2-player rules image)

recommendation: For 2-player Modern American Canasta: Deal 15 cards per player. Draw 2 cards each turn. Must have 2 canastas to go out. Use two decks. Follow standard MAC rules otherwise.

author: Janice Satterlee
question: I called a special hand. I started laying out my cards when I realized my partner and I had more points already on the table than my special hand was worth. I did not lay down all my cards. Could I have picked my cards up and not call the special hand?
context: Player started laying down special hand then wanted to abort when realizing table points exceeded special hand value

responses.author: Phyllis Altman Braverman
responses.text: No you can't pick up cards once they are down. Down is down

responses.author: Sharon Cuddy
responses.text: What's your partner melds you can no longer go for a special hand

responses.author: Robin Levine
responses.text: Special Hands are more often than not, the first meld for your team. If your group has the table rule that allows courtesy...

responses.author: Stacey Perlin Labell
responses.text: If you said special you can't take back.

responses.author: Susan Silberstein
responses.text: Laid is played AND once your partner has melded, the rule is that you have ONE turn only to play a Special Hand. It is called courtesy.

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: Table rule

responses.author: Donna Weinstein
responses.text: Well, that's a big mistake when you go by the rule, a card laid is a card played.

responses.author: Rhea Abelson Feinberg
responses.text: Once you meld. You can not do a special hand. Never heard that one.

responses.author: Marci Schwartz
responses.text: Only allowed one time around for special hands

recommendation: No. Once you begin laying down cards, you cannot pick them back up. 'Down is down' / 'Laid is played' is a fundamental rule. Additionally, evaluate whether a special hand makes strategic sense BEFORE committing - compare the special hand value against your current table points plus going-out bonus.
complexity_note: The 'courtesy' rule allowing special hands after partner melds is a table rule, not universal
strategy: Always calculate whether a special hand is worth more than your current table position BEFORE starting to lay it down. Once cards touch the table, you're committed.

author: Mitchell Garber
question: It's early in the game and match. Would you meld 4 wild cards that meet the point requirement (I.e. 125 points)? After melding, I would get 4 cards from the pack. My partner may have wild cards. The other team hasn't melded yet. Almost all the cards are still in the deck. Very few have been discarded. Chances of closing the wild card canasta are high because there are 8 wild cards remaining.
context: Strategy question about opening with 4 wilds early in the game

responses.author: Jennifer Jackson-Strage
responses.text: It would depend. Are your opponents open? Did they use wilds? Usually I'd recommend 5 wilds. 4 is risky.

responses.author: Christine Allan
responses.text: Sometimes melding 4 is the only way to get on the board. I would do it also.

responses.author: Renee Weinberg
responses.text: I definitely would

responses.author: Elyn Haber Levy Supran
responses.text: I will very often open with no less than 5 wildcards, if at least one is a joker and it is early in the game.

responses.author: Brooke Nero
responses.text: I would if it was early in the hand and there were no other wilds on the table from opponents. There are 12 wild cards...

responses.author: Robin Levine
responses.text: I did just the other day, melded 2 Joks+2, 2s for 125 pt meld. My partner closed the wild card Canasta with the deck very close...

responses.author: Diana Hibbard LoCascio
responses.text: I would do it rarely and it would have to depend on the scoring and the rest of the cards in my hand...

responses.author: Alysia Ehrlich Carrillo
responses.text: I prefer to wait till I have five wilds in my hand. There's many times I don't get any wilds in a game so you never know...

responses.author: Amy Elberger Meisler
responses.text: Nothing wrong with putting down 4 wild cards early in the game. It's a gamble, but if you're a gambler it's worth a try.

recommendation: Opening with 4 wilds is a calculated risk. The community is split: some recommend waiting for 5 wilds for safety, while others say 4 is acceptable early in the game when most cards remain in the deck. Key factors: (1) opponents haven't melded yet, (2) most cards still in deck, (3) partner may contribute wilds. If you're a risk-taker and conditions are favorable, 4 wilds can work; if you prefer safety, wait for 5.
complexity_note: Strategic preference, not a rules question
strategy: Opening with 4 wilds is high-risk/high-reward. Prefer 5 wilds for safety. Consider: remaining deck size, opponent status, partner's likely holdings.

author: Maria Da Silva
question: After an initial meld, can you put down 2 of a kind with a wild? Lots of opinions on whether this can be done or not.
context: Question about whether you can meld 2 naturals + 1 wild AFTER your initial opening meld

responses.author: Susan Coty
responses.text: No. Think of 2 and a wild as bookends—can be used as your opening meld and closing (going out) meld. This applies if you're playing a base of 3. Wouldn't apply if you're playing base 5.

responses.author: Deborah Continelli Barenfeld
responses.text: In games that I play in you can. I think it's something that needs to be established with players before the game starts.

responses.author: Carole Baron Brandwein
responses.text: We don't allow it in my games after the initial meld or for going out. Just too easy to get.

responses.author: Robin Levine
responses.text: We play that you can. It's a table rule. The unofficial 'official' is that if you're playing Base 3 you can open with a pair and a wild and close with a pair and a wild. In Base 5, you can open with a pair and a wild but you have to close with 5 natural cards before you can add a wild.

responses.author: Debbie Meyer
responses.text: Most people play only when you first meld and go out. People feel putting down a pair with a wild during the game is too easy.

responses.author: Dianne Gianfelice
responses.text: It's a Table Rule. I play with several different groups. Two allow this. Others must be a pure of three. The latter is much better in my opinion.

responses.author: Kim Schermer Fetterman
responses.text: No!!!

responses.author: Robin Krant
responses.text: Table rule. End of story

responses.author: Estel Punsky Silverstein
responses.text: Some do some don't

recommendation: This is definitively a TABLE RULE - discuss with your group before play. Common approaches: (1) 2+wild only allowed for opening meld and going out (more common), (2) 2+wild allowed anytime (less common). When playing 'meld base 5,' you need 5 natural cards before adding any wild to a mid-game meld.
complexity_note: Meld base 3 vs base 5 affects this rule differently
strategy: Before playing, clarify with your group: can you meld 2+wild mid-game? Most groups restrict this to opening/closing only.

author: Lisa Yardeni
question: I'm confused about picking the pack when opening. Some players say that you need the points to open and you can only pick the pack if you have an additional pair in your hand. Other players say that you can pick the pack if it's a part of your meld. Is there a definitive answer or is this a table rule?
context: Question about whether you need a separate pair to pick pile when opening, or can use meld cards

responses.author: Devorah Ribak Turner
responses.text: Most tables play that if you meld your points with your own cards, you now can pick up the pile with one of your triple or if you have a double and a wild... You can also pickup with an additional pair that match the top card on the pile but is not counted as part of your meld...

responses.author: Estel Punsky Silverstein
responses.text: You must be able to meld without any of those cards from the pack

responses.author: Robyn Bross Cohn
responses.text: Wrong You must have the required point meld

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: You must have the meld requirement in your hand, for both the required points to open AND the clean triple. With that, you can lay out you open and pick the pack and continue to build on your opening melds, then discard any card. No talon.

responses.author: Christine Allan
responses.text: We play you need to meld first, then have two cards in your hand that match the top card in the pile in order to pick the pile.

responses.author: Robin Levine
responses.text: First rule of picking the pack and melding: You MUST have your meld point amount (125, 155 or 180) ALREADY IN YOUR HAND! With 888 AA2 992 and a meld requirement of 125 this equals 130 and meets the requirement... If the 8 was not part of your original meld but you happen to have 2, 8s in your hand at least, you can pick the pack if you have meld point requirement in your hand...

responses.author: Sheree Glickman-Mancuso
responses.text: You can pick the pack but cannot use that card for initial meld

responses.author: Lisa Yardeni
responses.text: So it looks like it's a table rule. Thanks everyone!

recommendation: When picking pack while opening: (1) You MUST have the required meld points in your hand BEFORE picking - the top card cannot count toward opening points. (2) You CAN pick the pile with either a card from your opening meld that matches the top, OR with an additional natural pair in hand. (3) After legally opening, the top card joins your meld. Some tables require a separate pair not used in opening.
complexity_note: The key rule: top card cannot count toward opening requirements. Whether you need a SEPARATE pair is a table rule.
strategy: When opening with pack: meld your points first (cards from hand only), THEN pick the pile if you have a matching pair (either from meld or separately in hand).

author: Robin Shane Rashkind
question: If you are opening for your team and use all your cards but one. Can you discard that one before picking up the 4 cards
context: Question about turn order when opening - discard before or after talon?

responses.author: Alix Kane
responses.text: Yes. If you're getting a talon, you just need a card to discard after you meld. If you're not getting a talon, you need one card to discard and one to hold in your hand.

responses.author: Heidi Sue
responses.text: That would be a table rule and not a very good one if you throw in your last card before you pick your three or four cards you have none in your hand that means game is over...

responses.author: Marsha Hazen
responses.text: I was taught you need one to hold and one to throw

responses.author: Rhonda Bornstein
responses.text: Yes

responses.author: Jackie Fellinger Shoenfelt
responses.text: Yes as long as you can pick your talon

responses.author: Marcia Sternlieb
responses.text: In my game you can but I played in other games that didn't let you. So I guess it's a table rule

responses.author: Adrienne Rosen Kahn
responses.text: She has too. You cannot do an opening meld with all your cards you must have a discard.

responses.author: Rhea Abelson Feinberg
responses.text: Play both ways. Table rules.

responses.author: Beverly Chassen Resnick
responses.text: Yes as long as you're able to pick up the talon

recommendation: This is a TABLE RULE. Most common approach: If getting a talon (opening from draw), you only need ONE card left for discarding. If NOT getting talon (opening from pile), you need TWO cards (one to hold, one to discard) because you can't empty your hand without going out.
complexity_note: Talon vs no-talon situations have different requirements
strategy: This is a TABLE RULE. Most common approach: If getting a talon (opening from draw), you only need ONE card left for discarding. If NOT getting talon (opening from pile), you need TWO cards (one to hold, one to discard) because you can't empty your hand without going out.

author: Ann Baker
question: A question came up in play yesterday. If you pick the pack on your initial meld, we know none of the picked pack can go toward the count for your initial meld. But can you use a card from the picked pack as your discard? Or do you have to have a valid discard in your hand before you pick the pack?
context: Question about whether discard can come from picked pack when opening

responses.author: Dara Collins
responses.text: Yes it can be from the pack! Great idea to set aside a valid discard before you start melding or adding to melds

recommendation: Yes, your discard CAN come from the picked pack. Best practice: set aside a valid discard before you start melding or adding to melds.
strategy: When picking the pack on opening: (1) cards from pack don't count toward opening point requirement, (2) you CAN use a pack card as your discard, (3) set aside your discard first to avoid confusion.

author: Felice Rosenzweig Flitt
question: If one teammate opens with dirty aces but doesn't have enough points to complete the meld, can their teammate open with clean aces? They already know their teammate has 3 aces...
context: Question about partner opening with clean aces after teammate showed dirty aces without enough points
recommendation: If a teammate attempts to open with dirty aces but doesn't have enough points (mismeld), the meld attempt is invalid. The partner can still open with clean aces on their turn - they're starting fresh. The key is: an incomplete/invalid meld doesn't restrict what partner can do.
strategy: A failed opening attempt (insufficient points) doesn't lock the team into that meld type. Partner can open with any valid meld on their turn.

author: Robin Hammer
question: When I first learned to play, if you were going down, as long as you had a pair in your hand and your hand added up to 125/155/180, you could pick the pack after you put out the required amount. Then I started playing with people who said no, you need to put down your cards and have them add up and then, have another pair cards in your hand to pick the pack. Is it just another rule that depends on who you're playing with?
context: Question about whether you need an extra pair to pick pack when opening

responses.author: Susan Shemin
responses.text: Two cards are not needed in your hand to pick the pack. All you need is a pair; that is, two of the same card that matches the discarded card.

responses.author: Beth F. Levine
responses.text: MAC allows you to pick the pack with your initial meld, as long as that meld meets the requirements for points. It does not matter if the pair you use is in the meld or left in your hand after the meld.

responses.author: Kathy Weisman Wolf
responses.text: You absolutely can take the pack with a card you are melding with as long as you have full count in your hand before you take the pack.

responses.author: Modern American Canasta
responses.text: The most widely played rule is that as long as you have the RPC and a Pure Meld without the top card, you can pick the pack to open. A reminder, if you are using a pair (not three cards) that entire meld does not count for points or a pure. The top card never counts for points or a pure. There is no rule that requires you use an additional pair to pick the pack.

responses.author: Bonnie Esserman Gershenzon
responses.text: You must have a meld and required points to pick the pack. You cannot need the top card for point count or meld.

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: As long as you go down or meld with your RPC. You can pick up the deck.

responses.author: Linda Gaddis
responses.text: We play that you must meld first, and then use two cards that are in your Hand in order to pick the deck.

recommendation: No extra pair required. In Modern American Canasta: (1) Meet your point requirement with cards from your hand, (2) Have a natural pair matching the top discard, (3) The pair can be FROM your opening meld or separate in hand. Key rule: top card cannot count toward points or pure meld requirement.
strategy: When picking pack on opening: no extra pair needed. Just need RPC met and a natural pair (can be part of meld) matching top card.

author: Sue Kline
question: Can you go out by putting a card on the table that is not a wild and then throwing your last card which is a wild or joker. Our game says no but other games say yes.
context: Question about discarding wild card face down when going out

responses.author: April Volponi
responses.text: Your last card is face down so it can be any card.

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: Yes, you can go out with a wild or joker - it's your last card and it's face down - turn over - no one sees it.

responses.author: Barbara Magliozzi
responses.text: Yes as it is face down.

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: Yes. You can play a card to an open meld and discard a wild/joker face down if you are going out.

responses.author: Beth F. Levine
responses.text: In MAC, if you are going out, when going out, you discard any card face down. So throwing a wild is fine in that case.

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: In our game you cannot because we play if you have a non wild card to throw you must throw that.

responses.author: Christine Allan
responses.text: We don't allow you to throw a wild card to go out if you have a non wild in your hand. Must throw the non wild and add the wild to something on the table.

recommendation: Yes, in MAC standard rules you CAN discard a wild card face down when going out. Your final discard goes face down and can be any card, including wilds. Some tables have house rules requiring you to meld wilds if you have non-wilds to discard, but this is NOT the MAC standard.
strategy: When going out, your final discard is face down and can be ANY card - including wild cards. This is MAC standard; some tables have stricter house rules.

author: Terri Golden
question: What is the official rule (not table rule) when someone closes a canasta with 8 cards and no one realizes it until later? Does the canasta count as closed? Are all 8 cards counted for base (+/-)?
context: Question about what happens when 8 cards accidentally end up in a closed canasta
recommendation: An 8-card canasta is technically a mismeld. If caught immediately, the extra card should be removed. If discovered later, most groups treat the canasta as valid (closed) and count all 8 cards for base points. Prevention is key - always verify 7 cards before stacking.
strategy: Always verify card count before stacking a canasta. If caught, remove the extra card. If discovered later, it's typically played as-is.

author: Petra Macintosh
question: If the cutter cuts the exact number of cards of the deal (i.e. 52) does he get bonus points?
context: Question about perfect cut bonus points

responses.author: April Volponi
responses.text: table rule (and fun). We give 100 points

responses.author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
responses.text: Yes in our game we give the cutter 100 points- just a fun thing to do

recommendation: This is a TABLE RULE, not official MAC rules. Many groups award 100 bonus points for a perfect cut (cutting exactly the right number of cards for the deal). It's a fun tradition, not a requirement. Clarify with your table before the game.
strategy: Perfect cut bonus is a table rule - not universal. Ask before assuming points are awarded.

author: Millie Arana
question: If only one card is in the discard pile and it's needed to complete a special hand can it be picked?
context: Question about whether you can pick the discard pile to complete a special hand

responses.author: Meryl Danitz
responses.text: No. You cannot pick a card from the discard pile for a special hand.

responses.author: Sondra Berman
responses.text: Yes you can, if it's the only card in the pile.

recommendation: No. You CANNOT pick the discard pile for any part of a special hand - not even a single card. Special hands (pairs, garbage) must be completed entirely from your hand and draws from the stock pile. The pile is off-limits for special hands.
strategy: Special hands = stock pile draws only. Never pick the discard pile, regardless of pile size.
complexity_note: Community split on this, but official rules are clear: no pile picking for special hands

author: Millie Arana
question: My team needed 180 to go down. All my cards added to 180, so I didn't have any left in my hand if I went down, but I would have been able to pick the talon. Could I have gone down?
context: Question about opening with all cards when you'd have nothing left in hand but would get talon
recommendation: No. You cannot open by melding ALL your cards unless you're going out. When opening, you need at least one card remaining in hand to make your discard at the end of your turn. Getting the talon comes AFTER discarding, so you need a card to discard BEFORE receiving the talon.
strategy: When opening: Meld → Discard → Talon. You need a card for discarding BEFORE you receive the talon, so you cannot meld all your cards on opening.

author: Susan T Williamson
question: I want to open with 5 wild cards. Do I still need a triple?
context: Question about opening with 5 wilds and whether clean triple is still required
recommendation: Yes, with 5 wilds you still need a clean triple. The only exceptions where you don't need a clean triple: (1) Opening with a SPLASH (7 natural cards = pure canasta = 500+ points), or (2) Opening with a WILD CANASTA (7 wilds = 2000+ points). With only 5 wilds, you must include a clean triple in your opening meld.
strategy: 5 wilds = still need clean triple. 7 wilds (wild canasta) or 7 naturals (splash) = no clean triple needed because they meet requirements on their own.

author: Sharon Cuddy
question: An hour game we do not utilize threes they're put aside and depending on how many they are for or against the team? Question is if you pick up a three at the turn, what do you do?
context: Question about what happens when you draw a 3 from the turn card (talon)

responses.author: Penny Goldner Reich
responses.text: Your statement and question are not clear. Threes get put off to the side. At the end of the round they are counted as follows: No closed canastas, threes are minus. One closed canasta, threes are neutral. Two or more closed canastas, threes are credited. Separate them by color. 1 = 100, 2 = 300, 3 = 500, 4 = 1000 points

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: If you pick a 3 at or after the turn card you would still put the 3 down and pick another card

recommendation: When you draw a 3 from the turn card (talon): place the 3 aside and draw another replacement card. You still get to draw again even after the turn card. Threes scoring at end: No canastas = minus, 1 canasta = neutral (0), 2+ canastas = positive. Per color: 1=100, 2=300, 3=500, all 4=1000.

author: Beth F. Levine
question: Aces were closed by team A early in the game. Later, team A picked the pack and there were 3 Aces in it. Before the player had the chance to get rid of one Ace, team B went out. Does team A incur a 1500 point penalty for having 3 Aces if Aces canasta was already closed?
context: Question about ace penalty when holding 3+ aces after already closing an ace canasta

responses.author: Lisa Fox
responses.text: Yes there is still a penalty. It doesn't matter that there was a closed canasta.

responses.author: Dawn Myones
responses.text: Yes

recommendation: Yes, there is still a 1,500 point penalty for holding 3+ aces in hand when the round ends, EVEN IF you already closed a pure ace canasta. Having closed the canasta doesn't exempt you from the ace penalty. The penalty is for holding aces in hand, regardless of what's on the table.
strategy: After closing an ace canasta, prioritize discarding excess aces quickly. Don't get caught holding 3+ when opponents go out.

author: Millie Arana
question: My team needed 180 to go down. All my cards added to 180, so I didn't have any left in my hand if I went down, but I would have been able to pick the talon. Could I have gone down?
context: Question about opening meld when all cards equal exactly the opening requirement, leaving nothing to discard

responses.author: Deborah Felsenheld
responses.text: Table rule for us. You need one card in hand to discard and have to have one card left in your hand. Talon doesn't count

responses.author: Meryl Danitz
responses.text: You need one card to discard. You always discard first and then take your talon. If it's before the turn card then you can use...

recommendation: No. You MUST have at least one card remaining to discard after your opening meld. If using all cards for the 180 point requirement leaves you with nothing to discard, you cannot open that turn. The talon comes AFTER the discard, so it doesn't help. You must wait until you can open while still having a discard available.
strategy: When planning your opening meld at 180, always reserve one card for the discard. The order is: meld, discard, then talon (if opening from stock).

author: Shoshana Fluss Pilevsky
question: Playing with some people they made a Canasta they close their canasta really quickly. Sometimes I do not know how many wilds or jokers are in that Canasta and I stopped them to count. I feel that I am being a little rude and stopping them, but I also feel they are quickly closing their Canasta and my partner and I do not actually see how many jokers are in their pile. Do you think it is rude of me to constantly ask them to check their Canasta?
context: Question about game etiquette when opponents close canastas quickly before you can see the wilds

responses.author: Susie Linder Rozanczyk
responses.text: Up to you to pay attention to what is on the table. I would not keep asking

responses.author: Beth F. Levine
responses.text: Part of the game is learning to keep track of cards, especially wilds, 7s & Aces. I am very bad at it. In a friendly game, people might not mind your asking them to slow down so you can keep track, but in more competitive games the other team might get annoyed.

responses.author: Meryl Goldberg Lightstone
responses.text: One should ask if you can not see what cards they used to close the canasta.

responses.author: Lori Labrecque
responses.text: Not rude at all. It is not polite etiquette to close the canasta up before everyone at the table sees it.

responses.author: Ginger Lindsey
responses.text: The person closing the canasta too quickly for opponents to see how many wilds were played is being a little rude! It is possible to be competitive and still be friendly.

responses.author: Dana Ross
responses.text: I think it is ok to ask, and perhaps explain you are watching the wilds, especially if you have not yet opened. If they do not slow down, I would not ask any more than 2x.

responses.author: Brooke Nero
responses.text: If the top card on a closed canasta is black you can assume there is at least one wild but not more than two. Have to pay attention before it is closed. I would say it is rude to keep asking.

recommendation: It is acceptable to ask opponents to slow down when closing canastas so you can count wilds. Good practice: (1) Pay attention during play to track wilds, 7s, and aces. (2) You can politely ask once or twice for them to slow down. (3) Black card on top of closed canasta = 1-2 wilds. (4) Discuss expectations before game starts.
strategy: Track wilds actively during play. Black-topped closed canasta = 1-2 wilds. Ask politely if needed but develop your counting skills.

author: Anne Bombard
question: Regarding closed canastas, 8's for example, if there is a closed canasta with 88888WW, there are 3 8's left, can these be melded after the 8's canasta has been completed? Prior to completing a canasta, could both teams have melds of 8's?
context: Question about what happens to remaining cards of a rank after canasta is closed - are they dead?

responses.author: Meryl Danitz
responses.text: Once the 8's (per your example) canasta was closed, the 8's are now considered a 'dead' card and can no longer be melded. They are however now a safe discard to use against your opponent picking the pack. Regarding the second part of your question, Prior to the 8's canasta being closed, you are free to meld 8's.

responses.author: Penny Goldner Reich
responses.text: Once a Canasta is closed, the same card cannot be used by the opponent. If the Canasta is open, then yes, the opponent can use the same card.

recommendation: Once a canasta is closed, that rank becomes 'dead' - remaining cards of that rank CANNOT be melded by anyone. They become safe discards. However, BEFORE a canasta is closed (while still open as a meld), both teams CAN have melds of the same rank.
strategy: When a canasta closes, that rank dies for everyone. Use remaining cards of that rank as safe discards - opponents can't pick the pile with them.
